the key idea behind rainforest was making this notion of QA compatible with the notion of continuous delivery um
because Russell and I both had many times kind of built out a deployment and
delivery process at various different places and every time the bottleneck was the QA process um and I'm sure that's
very familiar to people here either you invest a ton of time and Engineering energy in order automation so that you

you're held back from continuous delivery by the QA cycle so that's like the fundamental kind of problem that we

set of regressions every single time we release because we're an Enterprise software or Finance or whatever it is so
we think of this thing called continuous QA as basically being the bridge between these two worlds the bridge between kind
of CI you know you're running all of your your kind of um unit tests and stuff in development continuously and

powered regression testing a seamless part of that um so then there's a bunch of stuff
about basically what does continuous QA look like I think the important stuff is that it has to be available 24/7 right
so not like maybe your QA team uh in house or maybe you have one in India
right these guys have a time zone they have working hours but ultimately you your developers might want to push to
production at 3:00 a.m. um and one of our customers actually does that um and
so 247 availability is really important um has to be super fast right because as
we all know as soon as you start sitting there waiting for your stuff to hit production the longer it takes the more
distracted you are and the less valuable that whole continuous delivery idea is um has to be cross browser I think most
of us today probably don't test comprehensively across all the browsers our customers use or important for the
business just because that takes too much time and I think the most important thing for us was has to have a really
great API so that you can run and retrieve your results all
programmatically um with the core objective to ultimately be the human work that you you and your team do is
creating and maintaining the test cases um but then the the runs and the results
are all kicked off as part of a continuous delivery push managed by Circle or bamboo or whatever it is
you're using so a bit about rainforest so or a bit
more about rainforest I suppose so in average we we have results in
kind of under 30 minutes we aim for 20 minutes we found 20 minutes to be the um
the kind of sweet spot for continuous delivery and by results we mean an average test Suite size of 50 tests
running in an average of five browsers that kind of average completion time all
of those tests take to come back to you um is about 20 minutes so it's incredibly fast and how we do that as
you'll learn in a second is through massively parallelized execution by sending 500 1,000 2,000 humans to your
staging environment all at once um as you can see there's 50,000 testers that's the monthly active number daily
active hovers between 5 and 10,000 um 24/7 availability and fully cross
browser so you may be thinking well this all sounds fine but where does this fit

QA today you can and and this is a a slide from our fundraising deck so apologies for the um illegibility of it
but there's two basic ways to do QA today right you can hire humans and so
that's a spectrum all the way from you know having your poor product managers do it in-house or you'll support people
all the way to having kind of a 5,000 person outsourced organization um or you
can do automation um and I think the fundamental thesis of rainforest is that
automation isn't the answer for the majority of web and mobile application
testing um and I think that probably there's lots of diverse perspectives
about um how effective automation can be within the room but ultimately what we've seen is that having a test code
base living and piggybacking on top of your actual application code base
eventually slows you down or requires you to invest huge huge amounts into quality engineering and so we think that
automation can coexist with a kind of human powered QA if that human powered QA is fast enough and so what most of
our customers do they see us as kind of the first QA hire right so zenefits is a

and uh basically what happened was they chose rainforest and so now they have 150 people in their engineering

and it's powered by via humans so they have humans all over the world that sign up to get paid to do tiny tasks you can

the bigger requesters tend to do um so it's the coolest thing is it's elastic
so unlike something like contractors where you would have to hire a thousand people to be around all the time you can
put work on and then it'll be done and how quickly you want it done is not
really configurable but you can play with that based on how much money you're charging and how you treat your workers

rainforest in MK uh so we've basically built uh a lot of custom stuff on top of
M Turk to make it do what we want um so we take workers who don't know anything
about QA necessarily they may but they may not and we automatically train them um so there's a whole system that we've
built that takes a a fresh worker who knows how to use a computer but may not know anything about QA and we teach them
our style of QA testing automatically uh behind the scenes as well there's a lot of technology to make

key part of rainforest and why it's so useful is that we've given the testers

think of it as a two-sided Marketplace for testing so customers pay us we pay
we put work out and workers get paid to do it um so so yeah we manage the entire

them up or also firing them so um the tooling that we have today um we
actually run in a custom infrastructure so it's like dedicated service
unfortunately can't yet use ec2 but we're we're working on that um and

um so um traditional workflow um for developers is a interesting one to to
think about most orgs that have some kind of QA or even if they don't have QA
um end up doing something like this they'll write code as an individual developer and then they'll write tests
and then they'll push it to CI and ask it to be reviewed um and then maybe
they'll get QA sometime later like basically it's normally requested that a

timings but the problems are when you fail when something goes wrong it normally gets pushed back nearly to the

breaks plus the cycle is really really slow so this is obviously the only way
you can do QA with the traditional QA org um but with a uh with rainforest um
the the workflow is slightly different so you can write your code and the developer or a PM can write the test FR
